title: Accurate WiFi-Based Localization of Dementia Patients For Caregiver Support: Phase II
description_brief: In this Phase II SBIR project we will enhance a wireless WiFi-based insole that was designed and successfully tested during a Phase I trial with elderly persons with dementia and their caregivers, and then investigate its efficacy in terms of caregiver activity, burden, and quality of life in Phase II. Evaluation will use semi-structured interviews and participant observation data collected from professional and family caregivers of patients with moderate or mild dementia.
description_detailed: The efficacy of the Activlink system offering localization information to improve caregiver will be evaluated in two studies. Study 2a will use the insole system with dementia patients residing in skilled or memory care. Data regarding caregiving activity will be collected from their paid professional care providers. Study 2b will use participant localization data collected on 80 independently dwelling mild dementia patients. In this case data will be collected from their unpaid family caregivers. Both studies will result in evaluating the efficacy of the WiFi-based insole to provide caregivers with augmented patient awareness, helping to improve their immediate quality of life by reducing their direct burden of continuous oversight of their person in care.

groups.title: Residents in Memory Care or Skilled Nursing Facility
groups.description: Activlink insole: Dementia patients will wear the provided insole inserted into their own shoes. The insole will have a small electronic sensor that measures acceleration, foot force, and/or orientation.

categories.title: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

measures.title: MiniMental State Exam
measures.description: Total score was used. Scores ranged from 0-30. A higher score indicates better cognitive functioning.
measures.populationDescription: MMSE data collected on residents only not on staff

outcomeMeasures.title: Caregiver Activity Survey
outcomeMeasures.description: Validated scale requires caregivers to report on amount of time spent caregiving for a particular patient. It has high test-retest reliability. Caregivers will be asked to complete this instrument once every two weeks. The scale describes the total number of minutes spent daily on six different caregiving activities. Therefore the minimum value for each item is 0 and the maximum is 1,440 for each item. Higher scores on each item mean more time spent caregiving.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: TIme reported by professional care giver spent in caring for monitored resident

outcomeMeasures.title: Zarit Caregiver Burden Scale
outcomeMeasures.description: This is validated instrument designed to reflect what people sometimes feel when taking care of another person. Caregivers will be asked to complete this instrument once every two weeks. Total score was calculated. Scores ranged from 0-48 with a higher score indicating greater caregiver burden.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: No data were collected for this measure because the nurse practitioners failed to respond to the surveys biweekly.

outcomeMeasures.title: AD Quality of Life Scale
outcomeMeasures.description: Assesses Caregiver quality of life with 13 questions rating from poor to excellent. Caregivers circle their responses. Caregivers will be asked to complete this instrument once every two weeks. Total score was calculated. Scores ranged from 13-52, with a higher score indicating better quality of life in caregivers.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: No data were collected for this measure because nurse practitioners failed to complete the biweekly survey.

outcomeMeasures.title: Device Accuracy
outcomeMeasures.description: Percentage of physical checks where device displayed correct location of patient/resident. Only partners reported on the accuracy. No data were required from participants. Therefore, they were entered as 0s in the chart.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: In validation phase of study, Nursing assistants were sent intermittent prompts to compare location of resident as indicated by the device to actual physical location of patient as determined by direct observation.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: First month of overall study period

groups.title: Nurse Assistants Recorded Data From Residents in Memory Care or Skilled Nursing Facility
groups.description:
Activlink insole: Dementia patients will wear the provided insole inserted into their own shoes. The insole will have a small electronic sensor that measures acceleration, foot force, and/or orientation.

Nurse assistants, which are the partner group in the study, reported accuracy of device for each participant. Participants were not required to complete this outcome.

adverseEventsModule.timeFrame: Full study period of 6 months for each participant.
adverseEventsModule.description: Care partners engaged only in observation and survey reporting and were not considered at risk for adverse events of any type including all-cause mortality.

otherEvents.term: Accurate WiFi-Based Localization of Dementia Patients For Caregiver Support

limitationsAndCaveats.description: Participants from study 2A discontinued before the end of the intervention period, and caregiving nurse practitioners failed to respond to the surveys biweekly. Only 4 surveys were collected by the end of study 2A. Largely because of the Corona Virus 19 pandemic all contacted participants from study 2B declined or withdrew consent of baseline data collection and treatment implementation. Therefore, no data were collected for this phase of the study.

explanation_target: Reason: The intervention described is a wireless WiFi-based insole (Activlink) and companion phone application intended to localize persons with dementia so caregivers can monitor them. The planned outcomes are caregiver activity, burden, and quality of life—i.e., an assistive/monitoring device to support caregivers rather than a therapeutic drug or biologic intended to modify Alzheimer pathology or directly improve cognition or neuropsychiatric symptoms. citeturn0search1turn0search0

Act: Key extracted details — device name: Activlink insole (with Activlink Phone Application); study type: Phase II SBIR (NIH R44 AG046944); primary evaluation: caregiver burden and quality of life using interviews/observation; registry identifier reported: NCT03360019. These sources confirm this is a device/assistive-technology trial, not a drug trial. citeturn0search1turn0search0

Reflect: Given the category definitions: (1) disease-targeted biologic — no (no biologic/antibody/vaccine); (2) disease-targeted small molecule — no (no small-molecule drug); (3) cognitive enhancer — no (no drug intended to directly improve cognition); (4) neuropsychiatric symptom improvement — no (primary aim is localization to reduce caregiver burden, not to treat agitation/depression). Therefore the correct classification is 'N/A' (does not fit any of the four therapeutic categories). If a separate category for assistive devices were available, this trial would belong there. citeturn0search3turn0search5

Web search results (sources used):
- SBIR.gov award page for 'Accurate WiFi-Based Localization of Dementia Patients For Caregiver Support' (R44 AG046944) describing the Activlink insole, aims to reduce caregiver burden / improve QoL. citeturn0search1
- Clinical trial listing (NCT03360019) and related trial registry entries describing the Phase II study using the Activlink insole and phone app and listing caregiver burden / AD QoL as outcomes. citeturn0search0turn0search3
- Supplemental SBIR/ASTER Labs descriptions of the Activlink/Activtrace insole system as an indoor/outdoor localization and monitoring device (device/technology details). citeturn0search6
